Approximately 3 weeks ago, he had an anterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction, which was treated with intravenous alteplase. He was discharged home in a stable condition. Current vital signs include a temperature of 38.1 (100.5°F), blood pressure of 131/91 mm Hg, and pulse of 99/min. On examination, heart sounds are distant and a scratching sound is heard on the left sternal border. ECG reveals widespread concave ST elevations in the precordial leads and PR depressions in leads V2-V6. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient condition?

The clinical presentation of a 72-year-old man with difficulty breathing, sharp chest pain that worsens with lying down, radiation to the scapular ridge, distant heart sounds, scratching sound on the left sternal border, and ECG findings of widespread concave ST elevations in the precordial leads and PR depressions in leads V2-V6 is highly suggestive of acute pericarditis.

Given the patient's recent history of anterior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (MI) treated with alteplase, it is important to consider post-MI complications. In this case, Dressler syndrome, which is a type of post-MI pericarditis, is the most likely cause of the patient's current condition.

Dressler syndrome typically presents 2-6 weeks after an MI and is characterized by pericarditis, fever, pleuritic chest pain, and pericardial effusion. The scratching sound (pericardial friction rub) heard on auscultation is a classic finding in pericarditis.

Management of Dressler syndrome includes anti-inflammatory medications (such as NSAIDs) and sometimes corticosteroids. Close monitoring for complications like pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade is essential.

It is important to confirm the diagnosis through further investigations such as echocardiography and potentially cardiac MRI, and to involve cardiology for appropriate management and follow-up.
